removals.reasoning: The outer parentheses around the cast result are redundant. The cast syntax (double*)ex already groups correctly; the extra parentheses add no precedence and hurt readability.
Same as above: outer parentheses around the cast are unnecessary.
Same: remove redundant outer parentheses around the cast.
Same: outer parentheses around the cast are unnecessary.
Outer parentheses around the cast are redundant in a function call argument.

The outermost parentheses around the cast expression passed to free are unnecessary; leaving the cast parentheses is sufficient and clearer.

Parentheses around the single variable operand of a cast are unnecessary; (double)i is the idiomatic form.
Parentheses surrounding the entire index expression inside the array subscript are unnecessary; array indexing accepts the expression directly and removing them improves readability.

The outer grouping parentheses around the whole RHS are redundant. Also the cast forms (double)(i) and (double)((j + 1)) can be simplified to (double)i and (double)(j + 1); these changes do not alter precedence and make the expression cleaner.
Remove unnecessary parentheses around the array index expression.
Outer grouping parentheses are redundant and casts around single variables can drop the extra parentheses; readability improves without changing semantics.
Remove unnecessary parentheses around the array index expression.
Remove redundant outer parentheses and simplify cast operand parentheses where they are around single variables; precedence is preserved.
Addition and subtraction have the same precedence and are left-associative; the extra parentheses around the numerator are unnecessary.
Parentheses around the index expression are unnecessary. (Note: the arithmetic 0 * ny + j could be simplified to j, but this change only removes redundant parentheses.)

removals.replacement: ey[i * ny + j] = ey[i * ny + j] - 0.5 * (hz[i * ny + j] - hz[(i - 1) * ny + j]);
removals.reasoning: Remove redundant parentheses around array indices and the outermost grouping around the subtraction. Keep the inner parentheses around the hz difference to preserve the intended multiplication scope (0.5 * (...)). This improves readability without changing precedence.

removals.replacement: ex[i * ny + j] = ex[i * ny + j] - 0.5 * (hz[i * ny + j] - hz[(i * ny + j) - 1]);
removals.reasoning: Remove unnecessary parentheses around indices and the assignment RHS outer grouping. Keep the necessary inner parentheses that group the subtraction being multiplied by 0.5.

Remove redundant parentheses around array indices and the outermost grouping of the RHS. The multiplication binds tighter than subtraction so 'hz[...] - 0.699... * (...)' is correct; inner groupings that clarify the intended subtractions are kept but redundant nested parentheses are removed to improve readability.
The outer parentheses around the casted address are unnecessary. Using (uint8_t*)&dim_thread_256_packed is the idiomatic, clearer form.
Remove redundant outer parentheses around the casted address expression passed to memcpy; this does not change semantics.
Remove redundant outer parentheses around the casted address arguments passed to memcpy. The simpler form is clearer and equivalent.
Parentheses around the format variable and around the array index are unnecessary. Removing them improves readability without affecting behavior.
Same as previous: remove redundant parentheses around the argument and index expression.
Same: removing unnecessary parentheses around the format and index expression.
Parentheses around the single argument 'newline' are redundant and can be removed for clearer code.
